813F9791DFD8447FAC3FFEAC99D71FB8.description: Create artworks inspired by ancient Egypt and ancient China

D9D79D241DF3406BA8FC06564F4C2E22.description: View artworks from prehistoric times as an inspiration for talking about and creating art.

1DBE3324CD2F46B4A75F9AB6332A3234.description: Explore a variety of artworks from local communities.

3274DC0691544A59805108DFF003581D.description: Share personal experiences with visual arts

1FB52F3A5B384AA69AC92B747C45E6B2.description: Knowledge about people who lived a long time ago can be gained through artworks

E4E05B29AFEB4F8F8B6416BFA69D76FC.description: Ancient societies used artworks for a variety of functions

E2C68C4B024F470BB7CFBA69C0EF2E40.description: Visual arts can have a specific function in a community

B5137038B72E4CB7A1BC1CDEFAE51DBE.description: The Great Wall of China is an example of architecture that was built for the purpose of protecting China

00510839AE2B477AB4D370D5BB78B783.description: Ancient sculpture and architecture may have been created to serve a religious or spiritual function, as seen in Great Temple of Amon Temple of the Queen Hatshepsut The Great Pyramids The Great Sphinx The Step Pyramid of Djoser The Terracotta Army

493799F6F6634EDD87C7F7D0933AC394.description:
Examples of how ancient societies documented ways of life can include Altamira Cave in Spain, 13 000 BCE Bhimbetka
Petroglyphs in
India, 290 000
BCE
Blombos Cave
Rock Art in South
Africa, 70 000 BCE
Lascaux Cave
Paintings in
France, 13 000
BCE
Newgrange
Passage Tomb in
Ireland, 3300 BCE
Petroglyphs in
Writing-on-Stone
Provincial Park in
Alberta, Canada,
1050 BCE
Stonehenge, Stone
Circle, in England,
1100 BCE
Venus of Hohle
Fels in Germany,
33 000 BCE

D8E40908911E49B181B2F3C66E000009.description: The function of the kite changed to become a popular form of entertainment and its design changed to include silk, bamboo, colour, bells, and strings.

5D23275786B144C794B005AF200EACCA.description: Kites were invented in ancient China and used by the military as a way to send messages and for measuring distances

93CDFDD44EE444E29B1CB8698B1D1467.description: Calligraphy was invented by ancient Chinese scholars.

597BACDA81F54DADB5AA112ED3CB0FF1.description: A function of artworks in ancient Egypt and ancient China was to record messages, including the alphabet (hieroglyphics) written on murals and the walls of the Great Pyramids paintings combined with ancient Chinese calligraphy ancient Chinese symbols for words or phrases (pictographs)

C18FC696C051492A9429E10C107DF784.description: From ancient times to present, artworks communicate ways of life, including culture enjoyment celebrations entertainment

B80DD5970A264116BAF6DA9AE21A2F9E.description: Students investigate the function of visual arts in ancient times and present day.

0B32E3151C6D43788F9BD09DF0B7D86E.description: Appreciation: Recognizing beauty, goodness, and truth in visual arts can be developed by understanding the complexity and richness of great artworks, the artists who create them, and the historical and cultural contexts from which they originate.

BA8D7532C2B14C76ACBD716D3378DF38.description: Create art as a means to practise and learn new skills.

366E6F2AC55A4DCC9AE0C9E508946024.description: Practise sharing and accepting ideas from one another when creating artworks

AFB5E0518BFC42C98F9C4B8D9FDFA8D4.description: Identify ways to solve visual arts problems or challenges

61741080C1224B9F970B335BE967D1DE.description: Collaborate to create criteria that helps determine when an artwork is finished

0335B016D6D1454B91C98DD3AE5013FA.description: Follow expectations or rules when participating as an artist or audience member

9596EA6381A241BFA51C9E7122E3863C.description: Participate as an artist and as an audience member in a variety of visual arts experiences

7267D0B3CBC842D79C704DBA45CDA825.description: Brainstorm ideas for creating titles for artworks

896120724F534936B106E5C7A5E4CE93.description: Collaborate with others when generating and representing an idea through visual arts

A641B942B9E244BF92749C9D37255EA5.description: Use a variety of media to create a landscape

5E4EAC36D0794EAFA38F1F8F32D61D9D.description: Create two- and threedimensional artworks using found materials

D3F3BEF31ADA4C34AA064767EB2F4031.description: Explore a variety of tools, media, and materials, including strings, wires, or tubes, when incorporating lines in artworks

EE053A0BB4E2410B8A99BCA320B4ECAB.description: Detail artworks using patterns and repetition

5F0E1C39045444C99B62804CF6517CA8.description: Experiment with artistic choices when representing ideas through visual art.

FA17ADE65F6647F38721CD3D593CA45E.description: Create artworks based on a variety of inspirations

36A2A54CAFD74EDCA2054CB885285E8F.description: Ideas that are shared and discussed can give artists inspiration for new ideas.

C1830BEA722643CCAEC35A68953E2A4F.description: Developing an idea through visual arts takes practice

B0602AFB772843B497DA28F387C89467.description: An artistic idea can come from brainstorming and collaboration

FB9D74C24BCC4AA486D0518BEDDA67D6.description: An artist is an individual who can create, appreciate, and present artistic ideas

7CC314D8501E4E98A8EAE2BD977B24F7.description: An artistic idea is expressed through the elements of visual arts

39F95C7165064E4FAFB3DFBF4AB17D98.description: Problems or challenges related to artistic expression can be solved by asking for help

CB345023DAD842A3A76FC08EC3759841.description: Developing an idea can involve practising or repeating a skill, or using tools, media, and methods in new ways.

8EB5468716924F51A1651D53671C0544.description: Participating as an audience member or artist includes expectations or rules (artistic protocols and etiquette)

389EAA6AECF74B5D91D9241A58C6A1B1.description: An artistic idea can be communicated by giving the artwork a title and presenting the artwork to an audience.

7496D7E197B94353AE311168E72282B0.description: Collaboration can foster a safe learning environment in visual arts through listening to others' ideas and making decisions

DEF724475647462DB5E97302EC17145A.description: Artistic ideas can express feelings, interests, and preferences

C291D24538CB4F1E8A352CE9AE427E85.description: Inspiration for an idea in visual arts can come from other artists and artworks stories imagination the environment music

576815F7139F4FBA9DBEB0B2CC5BF4CD.description: Repetition of line, shape, and colour can create patterns in artworks.

B6B69F6A716B4E19831FC97CF00E21E7.description: Two- and threedimensional shapes (forms) can be used to communicate an idea

C3304E426069427E83B5484454938657.description: Organic and geometric shapes can be created using a variety of tools, media, and materials

B9EF30471120438C93DFF3311F19D203.description: Media in art can include drawing painting sculpture fabric arts printmaking photography digital arts

6A06BA0AA9D74AD0AFA4C8ABA9C25189.description: Exploration of various media, tools, and materials can reveal artistic ideas.

88F9C41407B2457BADE0AC34D8B7E419.description: Students construct an idea visually using the elements of art

9C44D68C163D4CA39D95DB3A8063C4D0.description: Creating and Presenting: Ideas can be represented through artworks that draw upon foundational visual arts knowledge

6342535B1DD44A1E9EC2548BD3D2277A.description: Differentiate between open and closed shapes

6EDFC8796DE74809A4FEA632B14C6E81.description: Identify geometric and organic shapes in the environment and in artworks

673F09E34113489DAEB5422690F4EAE4.description: Observe the effect that combining various kinds of shapes can have on an artwork

66C3A270BFEF4BCF8C3BAF7802DD16C0.description: View artworks as a way to discuss how artists apply value, texture, and colour to shapes

FB6E9A6901824933ABDB6AEEB6B33018.description: Explore various ways to represent shapes in artworks

CAB096100ADE4C079274C33003DB69B9.description: Explore how to create a hard and soft edge in artworks

8E9AAAAE27F842B6AEBF27E8900EB38B.description: Identify shapes that have hard and soft edges

0B8FEF5969CE42E8B7636C557FAE4F93.description: Explore ways that lines can be used to achieve shading or texture in art.

03C721BEDBFC4405ADA3B04A22DECA89.description: Use visual arts vocabulary to describe value of line in artworks

D659FAC53519498DBB2A0E635C7E90D5.description: Explore how line can be applied in abstract artworks

E06ECEF6940B4E678BAD52DC16DE3EBA.description: View various abstract and realistic artworks to discuss the use of line.

066B531F9F66484FB0BF42C139941F58.description: Create artworks with a defined focal point or emphasis

8C60BD87EAD84E8C8ABB609AB6D25A83.description: Use visual arts vocabulary when describing the weight of a line

46F4B36F4A804CCCADCEBBAAE4690AED.description: Experiment with the amount of pressure needed to adjust the weight of a line when using a variety of tools and media

B3EA387ABDDE46428C3E92F8BEBEC902.description: Explore how contour lines can be applied to artworks

1CE94AD3366E4446BAA5D4AB125843E7.description: Demonstrate an understanding of line directions

037CDECA81324A7FBE5E31AE8EBB4082.description: Reproduce lines using a variety of methods, materials, tools, and media

8134BD84BE00449DB8BDC3DCD6065877.description: Use lines to divide a picture plane.

C426AD0AF42E437387D23D428BDDD761.description: Explore how lines can depict movement in artworks

FB5699BD688C458EA8B229F25BCC6A52.description: Describe the direction and physical characteristics of line in artworks.

49A256DFD91442B29E404112DB92B284.description: Shapes can come in various sizes and can be found everywhere.

1070119C0CDD4BAAACC56AA1F505C7D5.description: Shape can have value, texture, and colour.

765C4217C91F4EB7BD1FCEEA267B33E9.description: The boundary of a shape can be referred to as an outline, an edge, or a contour.

2D7EFDF7C6C94AECBAFEF333EC3163A8.description: Value describes how light or dark a line can be.

9DBCD3FB3284482489F6D65D6A0A6B71.description: Line represents and communicates ideas, feelings, and thoughts

A24826AB7BE94C4C8EF4A85809DEC00C.description: Lines can create emphasis in artworks

EEE23EDF6C3C41DCB58C750B333A68C5.description: Line indicates an edge that is known as a contour

439B027858A0462E9FB24ADA6B5817D3.description: When line is enclosed, it creates a shape in artworks.

AA4053DDF6A44128B563AF1C16DCD8E5.description: Line is created from a moving point.

C71B9E3A236143B485C3138E56FE2FEB.description: Line is an element of art

5576DAC41EFA43E8BCE283D824AE157C.description: Closed shapes are formed when lines are connected and spaces become enclosed

6320E52F56A844739E0E86ABAA1BC7BF.description: Shapes can be open or closed.

7F692AD254F24EC0B55EA53F7BDB7D9D.description: Shapes can represent many things, including animals, buildings, and people.

F3FDF94AFF244A04AECF1292490E5D52.description:
Shapes can be used individually or combined in artworks, as seen in Edward Steichen, Le Tournesol (The Sunflower), c. 1920 Giuseppe Arcimboldo, Spring, 1563 Henri Matisse, L'Escargot (The Snail), c. 1953 Joan Miró, The Harlequin's Carnival, c. 1925
Tim Pitsiulak,
Untitled (Bowhead
Whale)

BC353B743D6C4BFDBE2FCC40E9431F2F.description: Organic shapes suggest living organisms or natural forces found in nature, including rocks trees clouds animals plants

2F2771EA24AB46D1862CC3955704AB53.description: Geometric shapes can be found in nature, including spiral shells honeycombs snowflakes

343B394EFDDF42A2846F9BACFE786BB3.description: A geometric shape can be made of lines that curve, lines that are straight, or a combination of the two

B6808CED6FCF480A95BD8774A27074FE.description: Basic shapes are known as geometric shapes that have uniform measurements and form, including circles squares triangles rectangles

EE9F2059667F46019659C084FE5E29C6.description: Shapes can be classified as geometric or organic

11B9C8E43D83413B8D78AD812594F33B.description: Shapes can be used to create pattern and repetition in artworks.

8A0BE333D3A54E1AA23CD0E18BBACA26.description: Shapes can be created using various media and methods, including cutting ripping drawing sculpting painting digital media

DD7E8BA0D68F40D2BBE8222ACAFFA9DC.description: When shapes are combined or layered they can create texture in artworks

2A7ADC7E5F014BC8B6A6EDC8718F7379.description: Hard edges identify where one shape ends and another begins.

A7BDB1F5239D4CB89022816755374F53.description: Soft edges can give a general sense of a shape

C9118D7F46BB465B8B35E64CF77957B8.description: Soft edges make it difficult to identify where one shape ends and the next begins

52CBF9F1E97B4042AC9723965568F40A.description: The boundaries or contour of a shape can have hard or soft edges, as seen in various artworks? examples can include Alex Janvier, Lubicon, c. 1988 John James Audubon, Tropic Bird, c. 1827-1838 Maxine Noel, Not Forgotten, n.d.

BC1CF5C44E634B34ABB49AD578C85156.description: Hatching is a technique that can create shading and texture, including drawing fine, parallel lines close together and in the same direction.

1B0755C8CA7C4C00B0622191510FF499.description: Lines can create shading and texture, as seen in Albrecht Dürer, Young Hare, c. 1502 Käthe Kollwitz, Frontal Self-Portrait, 1922-1923 Nlaka'pamux Basket-making Rembrandt van Rijn, An Elephant, 1637, 1637

5C7E7E225721468A85D94B9DC4FC0597.description: Value can increase or decrease in lightness or darkness (gradation).

69B468E8590E4914B5F781902DD406C5.description: Explicit use of line in artworks can be seen in Juan Gris, Harlequin with a Guitar, c. 1917 Lawren Harris, Pic Island, c. 1924

3FC67BF16AC840C5A863B7276A6E3D86.description: Abstract art uses lines, shapes, and colours in numerous combinations to create an effect.

7E15424A571846ABAF65884B2CF2B96E.description: Abstract representations do not attempt to represent reality.

461952F7F8C3445EBA7DAC76898B26C5.description: Line can be used explicitly to represent subject matter in a simplified, abstract, or distorted way.

E34CBD964C0546DB8380E0D8A9F521D5.description: Line is expressive when physical characteristics are applied, as seen in Julie Mehretu, Empirical Construction, Istanbul, 2003 Lee Krasner, Gothic Landscape, 1961 Vincent van Gogh, The Starry Night, c. 1889

B65964F3A9F2479F87138EEB6E1811BC.description: Weight can be applied to physical characteristics of line and can be described as thick or wide thin or fine light or dark

1A3FEAC78E224D4F894415D699B9E187.description: The amount of pressure applied while creating lines impacts the weight of the lines

9C3308BFA8C94AB5A8D144C598C54A19.description: Line can be described as having weight, as seen in Maxine Noel, Spirit of the Woodlands, n.d. Pieter Bruegel, The Hunters in the Snow, c. 1565 Rembrandt van Rijn, A Woman and Child Descending a Staircase, c. 1625-1636

39F0EAB95F334E67A342C7D98B8E068B.description: Emphasis can make a line stand out in an artwork, as seen in Jonathan Borofsky, Walking to the Sky, c. 2004 Paula Rego, The Dance, 1988

47EAEE5515544BA28C484ED818AD31B5.description: Emphasis (principle of design) can be used to create a focal point in artworks

66122489CFA843C6917B2CF215E72AE0.description: A contour line can be perceived when two contrasting colours meet in a composition, as seen in Marc Chagall, I and the Village, c. 1911 Grant Wood, Parson Weems' Fable, c. 1939

37884907F163454F9B5CC519A1567FAC.description: A contour line defines the outer boundaries of or space around an object, as seen in Salvador Dali, The Persistence of Memory, 1931

3395B5DFEF574D699BF5570D880882C3.description: A line can be purposely added to an artwork (explicit).

7BF641A47A67416C84A12E877EEEB2AE.description: A line can be seen in artworks when two different colours or shapes meet (implied)

0FD64C1E70674FC6AF85DBC161080C4D.description: Line can be explicit or implied.

1EB052CDC7FC4C02977B211A691C402C.description: Physical characteristics of line can show movement, as seen in Diego Rivera, The History of Medicine in Mexico, c. 1953 Emily Carr, A Rushing Sea of Undergrowth, 1935 Lance Cardinal, Love of Nations, c. 2019 Natalia Goncharova, The Cyclist, c. 1913 Utagawa Hiroshige, Naruto Whirlpool, c. 1853

D9472D38878E4F199AD00CBDC9528670.description:
Direction of line can be seen in artworks and can include sculpture: -John Mawurndjul, Mardayin Ceremony, 2000 -Songye, Mask (kifwebe), c. 19th century CE -Terracotta krater c. 750-735 BCE architecture: -Himeji Castle, also known as White Heron Castle, in Japan -The Guggenheim Museum, in New
York, New York
Line has physical
characteristics,
including
short or long
thick or thin
straight or curved
dotted or dashed
zigzag
blurred or crisp 
Line can be repeated
to create patterns or
decorations.

52EAB14ED27B4C90ABC605B278891FF5.description: Lines have directions, including side to side (horizontal), up and down (vertical), and corner to corner (diagonal).

492EE3FCDB8B4D16A1AE1FC34B0FC552.description: Colour can be applied to line.

9C804A266E234B1F9954D1589A5B6DFF.description: Enclosed lines that create shapes in artworks can be seen in Henri Matisse, Icarus, c. 1947 Ivan Shishkin, Oak Grove, 1887 Prudence Heward, Rollande, 1929

19CBA35CB046424EAFBAB6F934A4BE12.description: Horizontal line can be used to divide a picture plane into interesting and varied proportions of sky and ground, as seen in landscape paintings or drawings.

2152F3DA43404FDDA82153ED5D430E9A.description:
A picture plane ncludes the sections
of an artwork, including
top, bottom, right, and
left.

5FF3FC1C0C6F422D8D202280EEF20D8B.description: A variety of tools and materials can be used to create numerous combinations of lines

E7D7765C0AA748C0BFF766C2CD776241.description: Line can be combined with other elements of art, including shape, space, value, colour, and texture

B5C9C49F969A4E8890673B4014F00EDF.description: Students connect line and shape as elements of art.

3496621785B14A24881D3EDD5F3C021C.description: Foundational Elements and Principles: Visual arts literacy is developed through knowledge and application of foundational elements and principles.
